Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Situation2: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Story:
I sat on the edge of my bed, phone in hand, staring at two unread messages. My mom had texted, “Can we talk tonight? Dad’s been quiet lately.” I knew she needed me to check in, to ask if everything was okay at home, to be the steady presence I’d always tried to be for them. But my phone buzzed again—this time, it was Mia. Her message was raw: “I can’t stop crying. Can you call?” She’d lost her brother just days ago, and I’d promised to be there for her, to listen, to hold her together when she felt like falling apart.

My chest tightened. I wanted to be the son who noticed when things weren’t right at home, who made sure my parents felt supported. But I also wanted to be the boyfriend Mia needed, the one who could help her through the worst pain she’d ever known. Both needed me now, and I felt pulled in two directions, guilt and worry twisting inside me as I tried to decide who to call first.
